Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Product has scheduled a general brainstorming session next sprint where attendance is optional
Story:
I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, half-listening to the chatter in the team chat about the upcoming brainstorming session. Product had scheduled it for next Friday, right in the middle of the day. Attendance was “optional,” but I knew how these things went—if you weren’t there, your ideas didn’t get heard, and you risked being left out of the loop for the next sprint. My manager had already nudged me, saying my input was valuable for the new feature set.

At the same time, my phone buzzed with a message from my stepbrother: “Don’t forget, Mom wants everyone at the cabin for the holiday weekend. She’s really hoping you’ll come this year.” I could almost hear the hope in his voice, the unspoken plea to be part of the family, to not be the one who always had a reason to stay away. I felt the weight of their expectations pressing in—my family wanting me present, my team wanting my expertise. My stomach twisted as I tried to figure out how I could possibly be in two places at once, knowing that no matter what I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
